articles.headline: Middle-Class Pay Lost Pace. Is Washington to Blame?
articles.snippet: A new paper by liberal economists presents evidence that policymakers helped hold down wages for four decades.
articles.abstract: A new paper by liberal economists presents evidence that policymakers helped hold down wages for four decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the most urgent questions in economics is why pay for middle-income workers has increased only slightly since the 1970s, even as pay for those near the top has escalated.

articles.headline: Activists and Ex-Spy Said to Have Plotted to Discredit Trump ‘Enemies’ in Government
articles.snippet: The campaign included planned operations against President Trump’s national security adviser at the time, H.R. McMaster, and F.B.I. employees, according to documents and interviews.
articles.abstract: The campaign included planned operations against President Trump’s national security adviser at the time, H.R. McMaster, and F.B.I. employees, according to documents and interviews.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A network of conservative activists, aided by a British former spy, mounted a campaign during the Trump administration to discredit perceived enemies of President Trump inside the government, according to documents and people involved in the operations.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: The Gateses’ Public Split Spotlights a Secretive Fortune
articles.snippet: Their marital estate is enormous and complex, containing assets as varied as stocks and farmland. Divvying it up could have implications for philanthropy.
articles.abstract: Their marital estate is enormous and complex, containing assets as varied as stocks and farmland. Divvying it up could have implications for philanthropy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fortune of Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates exceeds the size of Morocco’s annual economy, combines the value of Ford, Twitter and Marriott International and is triple the endowment of Harvard. While few know how their wealth will be divided in the divorce, one thing is clear: breaking it up can’t be easy.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish, David Gelles, Anupreeta Das and Kate Kelly

articles.headline: Israel Ground Forces Shell Gaza as Fighting Intensifies
articles.snippet: The surge in fighting left Israel in an unprecedented position — fighting Palestinian militants on its southern flank as it sought to head off its worst civil unrest in decades.
articles.abstract: The surge in fighting left Israel in an unprecedented position — fighting Palestinian militants on its southern flank as it sought to head off its worst civil unrest in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel launched an intense air and ground assault on the Gaza Strip early Friday, pounding targets with warplanes, artillery and tank fire in the largest single operation of a four-day conflict with Palestinian militants that had been waged by airstrikes from Israel and rockets from Gaza.

articles.headline: In Mixed Israel Cities Proud of Good Relations, a Sudden, Explosive Division
articles.snippet: Not even during the intifadas, the mass Palestinian uprisings of the past, did Israel experience such a surge of both Arab and Jewish mob violence.
articles.abstract: Not even during the intifadas, the mass Palestinian uprisings of the past, did Israel experience such a surge of both Arab and Jewish mob violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOD, Israel — The Arabs and Jews of Lod, one of the most closely mixed cities in Israel, have been through many upheavals. But they had never before seen the kind of intercommunity violence that unfolded here over the past three days.

articles.headline: Colonial Pipeline Paid Roughly $5 Million in Ransom to Hackers
articles.snippet: The payment clears the way for gas to begin flowing again, but it risks emboldening other criminal groups to take American companies hostage by seizing control of their computers.
articles.abstract: The payment clears the way for gas to begin flowing again, but it risks emboldening other criminal groups to take American companies hostage by seizing control of their computers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The operator of a critical fuel pipeline on the East Coast paid extortionists roughly 75 Bitcoin — or nearly $5 million — to recover its stolen data, according to people briefed on the transaction, clearing the way for gas to begin flowing again but complicating President Biden’s efforts to deter future attacks.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Nicole Perlroth and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: He’s a Dogecoin Millionaire. And He’s Not Selling.
articles.snippet: Glauber Contessoto went looking for something that could change his fortunes overnight. He found it in a joke cryptocurrency.
articles.abstract: Glauber Contessoto went looking for something that could change his fortunes overnight. He found it in a joke cryptocurrency.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last February, when Glauber Contessoto decided to invest his life savings in Dogecoin, his friends had concerns.

articles.headline: Beneath Joe Biden’s Folksy Demeanor, a Short Fuse and an Obsession With Details
articles.snippet: As Mr. Biden settles into the office he has chased for more than three decades, aides say he demands hours of debate from scores of policy experts.
articles.abstract: As Mr. Biden settles into the office he has chased for more than three decades, aides say he demands hours of debate from scores of policy experts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The commander in chief was taking his time, as usual.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Katie Rogers and Annie Karni

articles.headline: Guantánamo Detainee Agrees to Drop Call for C.I.A. Testimony
articles.snippet: Under a deal with the military court, Majid Khan, who has admitted being a courier for Al Qaeda, will give up his chance to call witnesses to his torture in return for being released as soon as next year.
articles.abstract: Under a deal with the military court, Majid Khan, who has admitted being a courier for Al Qaeda, will give up his chance to call witnesses to his torture in return for being released as soon as next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A detainee at Guantánamo Bay has agreed to a deal intended to lead to his release in the next few years in return for giving up the right to question the C.I.A. in court about its torture program, United States government officials said.
articles.byline: By Carol Rosenberg and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: A ‘Friend of Tom’ or ‘Can’t Be Bothered’: One Man’s Rules at Bank of America
articles.snippet: Thomas K. Montag, the bank’s No. 2 executive, has long run its markets and corporate banking division with favoritism and an iron fist, employees say.
articles.abstract: Thomas K. Montag, the bank’s No. 2 executive, has long run its markets and corporate banking division with favoritism and an iron fist, employees say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early on in the pandemic, Bank of America found an innovative way to gauge the success of the bank’s work-from-home experiment: a spreadsheet, distributed to team managers daily, that pitted the productivity of people working from home against those who were still showing up at the office.

articles.headline: Meet the Nun Who Wants You to Remember You Will Die
articles.snippet: Suffering and death are facts of life: “Everyone dies, their bodies rot, and every face becomes a skull.”
articles.abstract: Suffering and death are facts of life: “Everyone dies, their bodies rot, and every face becomes a skull.”
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Consumer Spending Flattens After March Jump, a Sign of a Rocky Recovery
articles.snippet: Retail sales held steady in April after rising 10.7 percent the previous month, as Americans continued to spend government stimulus payments.
articles.abstract: Retail sales held steady in April after rising 10.7 percent the previous month, as Americans continued to spend government stimulus payments.
articles.lead_paragraph: Retail sales were flat last month after a buoyant March, the Commerce Department said on Friday, as Americans continued spending their latest round of government stimulus checks.

articles.headline: Looking for Bipartisan Accord? Just Ask About Big Business.
articles.snippet: In surveys and political discourse, Republicans are increasingly critical of corporations, but not for the reasons Democrats have long held that view.
articles.abstract: In surveys and political discourse, Republicans are increasingly critical of corporations, but not for the reasons Democrats have long held that view.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republicans in Washington and around the country have soured on big business, joining Democrats in expressing concern that corporations wield too much influence. The shift has left corporate America with fewer allies in a tumultuous period for American society and the global economy.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley
